comments.commentBody: Re your patience. Read up on the myth of the Battle of Agincourt. Then imagine yourself and your fellow voters as the French and the Greeks as the English longbowmen. Get the picture?
Yes, but what are Germany's choices? The Wehrmacht?

Then leave the Euro. The German government should feel free to leave the euro any time.

The Greek government holds all the cards. If you haven't figured this out yet, you need to figure it out. Now.

the german electorate is also very real, professor,
and our patience with greece is wearing thin,
we don't take social hardship as an excuse for corruption, dysfunctionality and faked reforms.

This story is like the Seinfeld show -- a story about nothing.  Now we find out that the Department doesn't even preserve all of its own employees records on any systematic basis as public records.   Its hard to fault Hillary, who probably ended up preserving more than might have existed left to the Department's own methods.  The only one cheering on this story is Jeb Bush who thinks we should favor him because he put the drivel from his email online for people who have nothing to do to read.
Apparently Third Coast would hold Hillary to a standard that the department as a whole could not meet.  How fair is that. lol
If dot gov emails weren't saved that means more of hers were saved than anyone with a dot gov email.
No, it will not. Many who don't like her will tell you she's done, there's a reason for that, it is to depress people being optimistic for her, it's a political game. Don't listen to them.
Vikram.  I agree.   This is a non issue.  Let's talk about the economy.  Let's create more jobs.  Let's end wage stagflation.  But who cares about Hillary's e-mails?
Agreed. It is about the big picture eventually.

Really?  Who cares?  I don't.  Look at the larger picture.  Hillary vs. any Republican contender, and there is no comparison in terms of fairness, compassion, doing what's right, etc.  I think she's a little heavy when it comes to defending Israel, but in sum she is leaps and bounds beyond any Republican candidate.
The government already has all of her emails. And ours.

Hmm... Except that she was responsible for ensuring that the State Department preserve its records! How can she maintain, with a straight face, that her emails were being preserved because they were going to people with .gov addresses, including those at State? Sorry, but she was in charge of the State Department and, ultimately, the one responsible for ensuring the records were saved! She clearly did not want them saved!

Her replies have been so disingenuous and even outright falsehoods (as in all those emails with Bill, yet he's emailed only twice; or, that she went private because she didn't to carry two devices!). Do the Cali tons really thing that we're that dumb?!!
ewq21cxz - it's her intent that's important.  She obviously didn't know how inefficient her State Department was about maintaining records.

So if she had used State's servers, which her critics shrilly claim she should have, then none of her messages would have been saved since State wasn't doing that until this year.  And she's somehow in trouble.  This whole story is rapidly becoming a huge nothing that the media for some strange reason is hyping into some scandal that simply isn't there.
Sounds familiar.
Why don't you just call her and insist she tell you about planning Chelsea's wedding, worrying about being a grandma and the death of her own mother?

It seems that State did not intend for anyone to see them either.

In all those years State was receiving requests for information on Hillary's correspondence, it never divulged that it did not have access to Hillary's private server and, thus, could not fully comply with those requests.

Then there is the Obama Administration's complicity in State's obfuscation. It knew of her private server, despite its members' bending over backwards to claim they never emailed her (Jarrett).

And we are supposed to find fault with republicans' pursuit of Hillary's information. Turns out they were absolutely right about her.

Translation - The emails she hid on her personal server, she now claims were sent to the state department to cover herself, which the state department now can't find a record of, because they never received them. They were never received because they were never sent. Clinton never intended for anyone to see them.

If the NSA can record metadata on all communications of US citizens, the federal government can keep track of emails of its employees. Treat fed employees the same as US citizens (as potential terrorists), and I'm sure you'll see a way to record them efficiently.

As a parent watching my son use his laptop for math my view of technology is the exact opposite.  By the time he actually gets it booted up and to the website and password etc. he could be half way through a regular paper assignment.  It's hard for parent to see what he's doing on a laptop whereas a worksheet is perfectly transparent.  So I guess let's just see what the results are. I'm very skeptical of the benefits of technology and surprised so many parents are so enthralled by it.

Astronauts who have traveled high enough to see the whole earth at once have remarked about how fragile our beautiful blue planet appears floating in inky dark space. Looking at the earth's atmosphere, it appears alarmingly thin compared to the size of our globe.

One does not need to be 'a scientist' to grasp that pumping hundreds of billions of tons of CO2 and other greenhouse gases must have an effect, on the composition of the air and the increasing acidification of the oceans, resulting in increasing warming of our planet.

The reason this is getting so much attention is because of Hillary's expected presidential run, Republicans are desperate to find every little morsel they can to blow up into the next big scandal.

All it would take is to find 4 little words somewhere in all those emails to hang her, as they've done with 4 little words in the hundreds of pages of the Affordable Care Act.

Even if there's nothing bad in the emails, their absence can be the scandal in itself (which so far, it seems to be, but remember, some emails are already in the process of being redacted for release in a few months).

It seems email retention is a problem in many government agencies, but that's not what's being focused on here, it's just Hillary's emails.

The biggest problem I see with this is not that the records may not be available for official purposes (for the Republicans to use in a fishing expedition for something to use against her) and for public records, but that her private email server might not be as secure as it should be. But given Chelsea Manning's leaks of classified records from government servers to WikiLeaks, not using government servers may not be much more risky.

We should settle this,
we are talking about 11 Billion at most,
we should pin that against the 58 Billion we loaned greece in 2012 when we negotiated the 1953-alike bailout.

And about morality,
greece want to hold us responsible about something that happened 70 years ago and ended with a complete default,
but want to dodge their own responsibilities that happened 5 years ago.
I know, you can't compare a war with overspending, the end of the war was a cesura in history, that changed europe, and it changed for sure germany.
I don't see something like this happening in greece, this will go on and on, until every moral set-off has been exhausted.
Where the other SOS arrogant to use a personal email? Kerry's the first one to use a .gov.
And so here we are...her carelessness and utter disregard to her "public" are dwarfed by her arrogance.

Exactly, Clinton's personal use of email is one issue, the big surprise (not really) is that the government (to this day) does not have the ability to set up an email system that can track, store and archive emails.  This is not difficult!  I have a small company and we handle all employee email with Microsoft Exchange.  We have triple back-ups on our in-house server and one cloud backup.  This is not complicated stuff to set up, if I can do it with a small business you can't tell me the government can't do it with all of its resources?  My business does not deal with sensitive information.  Think of all the leaks taking place with the emails in the CIA, NSA, Dept of State, White House, etc.  The federal Government would be better off contracting out all email services to Google, let the experts handle it.  Unbelievable, total incompetence and this is what what my taxes pay for.  Time for a real change in Government!!!

Some commenters are saying Clinton's use of personal e-mail is no big deal with this latest revaluation about all gov't e-mail not being preserved - not true. What is true is that we wouldn't be talking about Hillary's lost e-mail if she used a .gov account - we'd just be discussing the gov't general lack of competence not Hillary's arrogance.

So if she DID have a govt email those same ones could have gone missing as well along with the other officials. So she may have preserved MORE than others. Why is your title making it seem like the other way around? But good to know that more could have been lost if she did have a government email.
and her political party.

...and with the fact that today's GOP has NOTHING to offer except negativity, carping, "We can't afford it!" whenever something will benefit the vast majority of our population, and endless war.
Why keep this issue going?

Oh please! Don't misuse the gender card on something like this and Hiliary's need for simplicity when there are so many other places which need our feminist voices to be heard. It is insulting to those of
us who worked for women's rights in the 70's and
80's.
Hillary followed all rules and did exactly what many other high-ranking officials did. Why the unusually high standard? Methinks it has much to do with her gender.

This is way beyond Hillary Clinton.  This is government incompetence at its best.  Expecting senior officials to decide if a given email was worthy of perserving, and if so they would have to either save it or print it out.  Sure, they have plenty of time for these things. Nothing more important going on. This could be just the issue the two parties could agree on to actually pass a bill to fix a problem.  Baby steps.
Just ask the NSA for their copies.
No. People who are not supporters would like people to believe that but it just is not the case.
Good flavor combinations, very satisfying for a meal.  We did half the recipe--1/8 tsp. cinnamon.

Exactly. Government bureaucracy is moving to all 'online' and that is a big mistake.

The internet is fine for simple straightforward cases. That's why it appears to be 'streamlined'.

However, if you have any further questions, concerns or special circumstances- it can easily become a frustrating nighmare.

There should always be recourse to knowledgeable, helpful navigators.
Face to face interaction should always be available.

Sometimes that is actually more streamlined than the internet.

Not true.  I was in the announcing booth for the match and quickly went to the press box. The press had no idea and the tourney scrambled to get a match on center court for broadcast and issue a statement.

Anthony I'm glad you included the date of the event you decided to highlight. I agree that there have been times when Serena was not the best sport in the game. But, like many of us she has mellowed with age and has gone on to be a better sport in winning and losing. I find it sad that others like you will NEVER allow her to forget or at the very least put to rest that stage of her career. Now if you wanted to be fair, go back in that time machine and pull up some of McEnroe's tirades, right down to threatening a line judge. Strange how he is now one of the old lions of the sport. Funny how that works...

Er, I saw that match. There was no foot fault. I was shouting at the referee too (at the TV). What is your point? That a player should never contest a referee who was obviously wrong? The silly foot fault calls cost her the championship. I thought Serena was very graceful in defeat.

Just out of curiosity, were you tut tutting, winking-jabbing when McEnroe was doing something far worse?

Would you please hold up a mirror to yourself?

Kalidan
ego, last laugh, $$$$, healing? who is healing if that's the intention?

There is not doubt that the William's sister's have witnessed the worst and best of the American public. They are the best female tennis players the world has ever witnessed. However, the comments here that glorify there character and place them on a high pedestal should not be driven by white guilt or black indignation. If America does not look honestly at itself and strive to improve how we see and treat each other then the American experiment will continue it's current slide downward toward massive social and economic failure. Below is a reminder that Serena has at times demonstrated less than model citizenship and sportsmanship. And by the way, what are her true motivations for showing up at a place her and her family adamantly swore they would never return?

------------------------------------------------------------
2009
...railing 4-6 5-6 15-30, Williams launched into a second serve but the line judge called her for a foot-fault, meaning the American had served a double-fault to go match point down. Astounded by the verdict, Williams launched into an expletive-laced rant at the official. She waved her racket in the lineswoman's direction and then shook a ball in her clenched fist as she threatened to "shove it down" her throat.

And she wins. Wasn't pretty but she did it. Her emotions were all over the place. Crowd was great to both players. Not sure I could have done what she did but hopefully she has conquered her fear.

Way to go Serena!!!!!!

by the way, the wikipedia article does a very nice job of explaining the difficulty of coming up with an exact date for the onset of a LIA, a point I raise for two reasons: a) Revkin's article's about the difficulty of coming up with a date for an Snthropocene, and b) tying dissolved CO2 to specific dates for the LIA is a little shaky.

Oh, and could we perhaps see some evidence for this absorbed CO2?

"Vast areas of farmland went back to nature for lack of serfs to work the land."

Dale, the world is a big place, stop being so Eurocentric. Europe had a small fraction of the world population; an even smaller fraction of world's standing forest crop. The people who lived were very wood hungry. There was no wide scale recovery of forests in Europe.

Dear Andy,

I have my doubts.

The outbreak of the Black Death in the 14th century was every bit as devastating to Europe as the introduction of smallpox was to the Americas. Something like one-third of the population died. The feudal system of nobles, knights and serfs suffered a body blow.

Vast areas of farmland went back to nature for lack of serfs to work the land.

Yet we see no comparable drop in CO2 in the ice core to that flagged as A.D. 1610. Why not?

The 16th Century population drop in the Americas was not in forested North America. It was in Central America and the Caribbean. Spanish enslavement of Tainos, Arawaks, Incas and Aztecs did indeed lead to widespread collapse of populations in Mexico and the Caribbean basin. (The Spanish brought in African slaves to replace the lost Indians) But that was not where the forests grew. There was very little 16th Century European settlement in what is now the Continental US and Canada, where most of the forests were.

2) The depopulation of Central America and the Caribbean in the early 16th Century was syncronomous with a deadly syphilis epidemic in Europe (Ref: Hermann, Paul, The Age of Discovery, p. 222) which significantly dropped the population of Europe at the same time population was dropping in the Americas. Yet we see no dip in CO2 in the ice cores. Why not?

Simplest explanation: cold sea water temperatures from the onset of the Little Ice Age led to more CO2 being absorbed into the ocean.
